greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Lexicographically earliest such sequence a that a(i) = a(j) => A046523(i) = A046523(j) and A048250(i) = A048250(j), for all i, j.
comment: Restricted growth sequence transform of A291758, which means that this is the lexicographically least sequence a, such that for all i, j: a(i) = a(j) <=> A291758(i) = A291758(j) <=> A046523(i) = A046523(j) and A048250(i) = A048250(j). That this is equal to the definition given in the title follows because any such lexicographically least sequence satisfying relation <=> is also the least sequence satisfying relation => with the same parameters.
link: Antti Karttunen, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..65537
program: rgs_transform(invec) = { my(om = Map(), outvec = vector(length(invec)), u=1); for(i=1, length(invec), if(mapisdefined(om,invec[i]), my(pp = mapget(om, invec[i])); outvec[i] = outvec[pp] , mapput(om,invec[i],i); outvec[i] = u; u++ )); outvec; };
A046523(n) = { my(f=vecsort(factor(n)[, 2], , 4), p); prod(i=1, #f, (p=nextprime(p+1))^f[i]); };  \\ From A046523
A048250(n) = if(n<1, 0, sumdiv(n, d, if(core(d)==d, d)));
results.author: _Antti Karttunen_, Nov 29 2018
